articles.headline: The Metropolitan Opera’s New Stage
articles.snippet: For 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera has wrinkled its nose at advertising campaigns. But next week, it is entering the fray.
articles.abstract: For 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera has wrinkled its nose at advertising campaigns. But next week, it is entering the fray.

articles.headline: Ramsey Case Suspect Cleared After DNA Tests
articles.snippet: John Mark Karr’s DNA did not match the evidence found at the scene of JonBenet Ramsey’s death 10 years ago.
articles.abstract: John Mark Karr’s DNA did not match the evidence found at the scene of JonBenet Ramsey’s death 10 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 28 — The case against John M. Karr in the 1996 killing of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey collapsed Monday when DNA tests refuted Mr. Karr’s claims that he had committed the crime.

articles.headline: Islamic Revival in Syria Is Led by Women
articles.snippet: The growth of Koranic schools for girls, rare in the Arab world, is a sign that Syria is becoming religious.
articles.abstract: The growth of Koranic schools for girls, rare in the Arab world, is a sign that Syria is becoming religious.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Enas al-Kaldi stops in the hallway of her Islamic school for girls and coaxes her 6-year-old schoolmate through a short recitation from the Koran.

articles.headline: Detroit Sees Cheap Gas as History
articles.snippet: The Chrysler Group said Monday that it expected gasoline prices to remain at $3 to $4 a gallon for the rest of this decade.
articles.abstract: The Chrysler Group said Monday that it expected gasoline prices to remain at $3 to $4 a gallon for the rest of this decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 28 — The Chrysler Group, which depends more heavily on sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles than any other Detroit automaker, said Monday that it expected gasoline prices to remain at $3 to $4 a gallon for the rest of this decade.

articles.headline: Cruise Gets First Funds for Projects
articles.snippet: Tom Cruise’s independent production company announced that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.
articles.abstract: Tom Cruise’s independent production company announced that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tom Cruise showed Hollywood the money yesterday, with his independent production company announcing that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.

articles.headline: Prudential to Pay Fine in Trading
articles.snippet: The $600 million settlement could end a three-year investigation into improper trading in the mutual fund industry.
articles.abstract: The $600 million settlement could end a three-year investigation into improper trading in the mutual fund industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prudential Financial, the life insurance company, agreed yesterday to pay $600 million to settle charges with federal and state regulators that one of its units engaged in inappropriate mutual fund trading.

articles.headline: Radical Militia and Iraqi Army in Fierce Battle
articles.snippet: Violence that killed at least 28 people amounted to the most brazen recent clashes between government forces and a Shiite militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, a cleric.
articles.abstract: Violence that killed at least 28 people amounted to the most brazen recent clashes between government forces and a Shiite militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, a cleric.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 28  At least 20 gunmen and 8 civilians were killed Monday when the Iraqi Army battled fiercely for hours with members of a militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric, in Diwaniya, Iraqi officials said.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Edward Wong

articles.headline: BMW’s Custom-Made University
articles.snippet: BMW’s $10 million gift to Clemson University in 2002 has led to some unusual privileges for the German automaker.
articles.abstract: BMW’s $10 million gift to Clemson University in 2002 has led to some unusual privileges for the German automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — When Clemson University received $10 million from the German automaker BMW in 2002, the money helped jump-start a $1.5 billion automotive research and educational center. It also led to a partnership that both the automaker and the university acknowledge has grown extraordinarily close.

articles.headline: Detroit Sees Cheap Gas as History
articles.snippet: The Chrysler Group, which depends more heavily on sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles than any other Detroit automaker, said Monday that it expected gasoline prices to remain at $3 to $4 a gallon for the rest of this decade.     The ...
articles.abstract: The Chrysler Group, which depends more heavily on sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles than any other Detroit automaker, said Monday that it expected gasoline prices to remain at $3 to $4 a gallon for the rest of this decade.     The comments by Thomas W. LaSorda, Chrysler's chief executive, are the first time a Detroit automaker has issued a specific forecast on gas prices since they began climbing to $3 a gallon and higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 28 - The Chrysler Group, which depends more heavily on sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles than any other Detroit automaker, said Monday that it expected gasoline prices to remain at $3 to $4 a gallon for the rest of this decade.

articles.headline: The Metropolitan Opera’s New Stage
articles.snippet: For 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera has wrinkled its elegant nose at advertising campaigns, preferring discreet sales tactics like direct mail and phone solicitations.      But next week, it is entering the mass marketing fray with ads in the mos...
articles.abstract: For 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera has wrinkled its elegant nose at advertising campaigns, preferring discreet sales tactics like direct mail and phone solicitations.      But next week, it is entering the mass marketing fray with ads in the most conventional places: telephone kiosks, lamp posts, subway entrances and the sides of city buses.

articles.headline: Radical Militia and Iraqi Army in Fierce Battle
articles.snippet: At least 20 gunmen and 8 civilians were killed Monday when the Iraqi Army battled fiercely for hours with members of a militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric, in Diwaniya, Iraqi officials said.      The violence, which one Ira...
articles.abstract: At least 20 gunmen and 8 civilians were killed Monday when the Iraqi Army battled fiercely for hours with members of a militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric, in Diwaniya, Iraqi officials said.      The violence, which one Iraqi general said included militiamen executing Iraqi soldiers in a public square, amounted to the most brazen clashes in recent memory between Iraqi government forces and Mr. Sadr's militia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 28 - At least 20 gunmen and 8 civilians were killed Monday when the Iraqi Army battled fiercely for hours with members of a militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric, in Diwaniya, Iraqi officials said.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Ramsey Case Suspect Cleared After DNA Tests
articles.snippet: The case against John M. Karr in the 1996 killing of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey collapsed Monday when DNA tests refuted Mr. Karr's claims that he had committed the crime.     The announcement by the Boulder County district attorney, Mary T. Lacy, ...
articles.abstract: The case against John M. Karr in the 1996 killing of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey collapsed Monday when DNA tests refuted Mr. Karr's claims that he had committed the crime.     The announcement by the Boulder County district attorney, Mary T. Lacy, incited a storm of questions about why Mr. Karr, 41, had been believed in his admissions and how he could have led prosecutors into what became an elaborate global farce. Hordes of reporters had tracked Mr. Karr's journey, from his apprehension in Thailand nearly two weeks ago to his return to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 28 - The case against John M. Karr in the 1996 killing of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey collapsed Monday when DNA tests refuted Mr. Karr's claims that he had committed the crime.

articles.headline: Prudential to Pay Fine in Trading
articles.snippet: Prudential Financial, the life insurance company, agreed yesterday to pay $600 million to settle charges with federal and state regulators that one of its units engaged in inappropriate mutual fund trading.      The payment, the second-largest lev...
articles.abstract: Prudential Financial, the life insurance company, agreed yesterday to pay $600 million to settle charges with federal and state regulators that one of its units engaged in inappropriate mutual fund trading.      The payment, the second-largest levied against a financial institution over the practice, may bring to a close a three-year investigation into the improper trading of mutual funds that has ensnared some of the largest names on Wall Street and the mutual fund industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prudential Financial, the life insurance company, agreed yesterday to pay $600 million to settle charges with federal and state regulators that one of its units engaged in inappropriate mutual fund trading.

articles.headline: BMW’s Custom-Made University
articles.snippet: When Clemson University received $10 million from the German automaker BMW in 2002, the money helped jump-start a $1.5 billion automotive research and educational center. It also led to a partnership that both the automaker and the university ackn...
articles.abstract: When Clemson University received $10 million from the German automaker BMW in 2002, the money helped jump-start a $1.5 billion automotive research and educational center. It also led to a partnership that both the automaker and the university acknowledge has grown extraordinarily close.     In return for the largest cash donation ever received by the school, Clemson gave the company some unusual privileges, including a hand in developing a course of study. Clemson's president drives a silver BMW X5 sport utility vehicle, compliments of BMW, whose only North American plant is 50 miles away.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. - When Clemson University received $10 million from the German automaker BMW in 2002, the money helped jump-start a $1.5 billion automotive research and educational center. It also led to a partnership that both the automaker and the university acknowledge has grown extraordinarily close.

articles.headline: Cruise Gets First Funds for Projects
articles.snippet: Tom Cruise showed Hollywood the money yesterday, with his independent production company announcing that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.     Hollywood's reaction? That's a good start, but show us more.
articles.abstract: Tom Cruise showed Hollywood the money yesterday, with his independent production company announcing that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.     Hollywood's reaction? That's a good start, but show us more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tom Cruise showed Hollywood the money yesterday, with his independent production company announcing that it had lined up financing from a wealthy sports entrepreneur.

articles.headline: Star of the Right Loses His Base at the Border
articles.snippet: He supports tax cuts and the war in Iraq. He opposes stem cell research and the Medicare drug plan. He is a master of his movement's medium, talk radio. Jesus Christ is his personal savior and Ronald Reagan his political idol.     Conjure what mig...
articles.abstract: He supports tax cuts and the war in Iraq. He opposes stem cell research and the Medicare drug plan. He is a master of his movement's medium, talk radio. Jesus Christ is his personal savior and Ronald Reagan his political idol.     Conjure what might be called the perfect conservative, and chances are he would look a lot like Representative Mike Pence, the Indiana Republican who in just three terms has turned 100 House allies into a vanguard and himself into one of his party's rising stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNCIE, Ind. - He supports tax cuts and the war in Iraq. He opposes stem cell research and the Medicare drug plan. He is a master of his movement's medium, talk radio. Jesus Christ is his personal savior and Ronald Reagan his political idol.

articles.headline: Clinton Makes Up for Lost Time in Battling AIDS
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton worked the crowd of AIDS survivors, clasping the outstretched hands of children alive because of the AIDS medicines his foundation donated.     Inside the rural hospital here that he recently helped renovate, where Rwandans were hunte...
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton worked the crowd of AIDS survivors, clasping the outstretched hands of children alive because of the AIDS medicines his foundation donated.     Inside the rural hospital here that he recently helped renovate, where Rwandans were hunted down and killed during the genocide he regrets he didn't try to stop as president, Mr. Clinton heard people once skeletal from AIDS tell of their resurrections to robust health.
articles.lead_paragraph: RWINKWAVU, Rwanda - Bill Clinton worked the crowd of AIDS survivors, clasping the outstretched hands of children alive because of the AIDS medicines his foundation donated.
